posts.subject: Is the Day/Night Line Close to a Normal Distribution?
posts.description: I noticed the solar terminator (the boundary between day and night on a world map) looks suspiciously like a normal distribution, so I tested it. Using the terminator's actual equation (arctan(-cos(λ)/tan(δ))), I fit a Gaussian curve across all four seasons and compared R² values. It turns out the solstices come closest (!) (R² ≈ 0.956), mid-February is decent but drifts (R² ≈ 0.865), and the equinoxes fall apart entirely. At the solstices, the terminator curve is ~95.6% bell curve / normal distribution, and in mid-February it's ~86.5%.
